item.title: Immaculate Constellation Alleged Pentagon UFO Data Concealment
item.description:
Immaculate Constellation: Alleged Pentagon UFO Data Concealment ðŸ”—

This article summarizes claims made by journalist Michael Shellenberger regarding a purported classified U.S. defense initiative called “Immaculate Constellation,” which he alleges is concealing a massive amount of UFO (Unidentified Aerial Phenomena) evidence.

Overview ðŸ”—

The core assertion is that the Pentagon is hiding a vast archive of high-quality data related to UAPs. This data includes photos, videos, radar information, and infrared sensor readings. Shellenberger claims that the amount of information publicly released is less than 1% of what has been collected.

Shellenberger’s Claims and Sources ðŸ”—

Michael Shellenberger, an investigative journalist and whistleblower advocate, is the primary source of these claims. He states that multiple government insiders and whistleblowers have provided him with information about “Immaculate Constellation.” One named source is former intelligence contractor Matthew Brown. Shellenberger alleges that the data held by this initiative is far more extensive than the limited clips released by the Department of Defense. He emphasizes the high quality and comprehensive nature of the hidden data.

Secrecy and Redaction ðŸ”—

The article highlights a pattern of excessive secrecy surrounding UAP information. Shellenberger points to declassified files where potential explanations for UAP incidents are redacted, leaving only vague references and blacked-out text. He argues that this level of secrecy is unacceptable, especially considering that taxpayers funded the research. He also claims that even Congress has been blocked from accessing the full picture.

Congressional Interest and Bipartisan Support ðŸ”—

The article emphasizes the bipartisan interest in UAP transparency within the U.S. Congress. Congressional hearings on UAPs have reportedly drawn large audiences and support from both Democrats and Republicans. Lawmakers are said to be increasingly frustrated by the Pentagon’s reluctance to share information, even with oversight committees. Shellenberger, who has testified before Congress, notes the growing public and political pressure for answers.

Potential Turning Point ðŸ”—

The revelations about “Immaculate Constellation” are presented as a potential turning point in the push for UFO disclosure. The call for transparency is no longer limited to civilian researchers but is now a serious matter being debated at high levels of government. Shellenberger believes that executive leadership needs to respond to public and congressional pressure and provide the full story. The article concludes by suggesting that the mystery surrounding UAPs may be closer to unraveling than ever before.

source: https://www.latest-ufo-sightings.net/2025/05/immaculate-constellation-journalist-claims-pentagon-hiding-massive-ufo-evidence.html

item.title: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024
item.description:
National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024 ðŸ”—

The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024 (NDAA 2024) is a United States federal law that outlines the budget, expenditures, and policies of the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) for fiscal year 2024.

Background ðŸ”—

The National Defense Authorization Act is an annual bill proposed in the United States Congress that redefines the United States military budget for the following fiscal year. Each chamber of Congress introduced a version of the NDAA: H.R. 2670 in the House and S. 2226 in the Senate.

History ðŸ”—

The House passed their version on July 14, 2023 by a vote of 219â€“210. Led by Chuck Schumer and Mike Rounds, the Senate passed theirs on July 27, 2023 by a vote of 86â€“11. The Senate then replaced H.R. 2670 with the text of S. 2226 and passed it by unanimous consent, and indefinitely postponed S. 2226. The House disagreed to the Senate amendment and asked to hold conference on September 19, with the Senate insisting on its amendment and agreeing to conference on November 15. The subsequent conference report was filed on December 6 (H. Rept. 118-301). The bill was approved by the Senate and House and sent to President Joe Biden on December 14. Biden signed it into law on December 22. In his signing statement, Biden expressed reservations about provisions that restrict the executive branch’s discretion in Guantanamo detainee transfers and raised constitutional concerns regarding congressional oversight and foreign policy authority.

Provisions ðŸ”—

This section requires updating to reflect recent events or newly available information.

Unidentified flying objects (UFOs) ðŸ”—

Sections 1841 et seq. outline the creation and management of a comprehensive collection of government records on UFOs or unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) at the National Archives (NARA), detailing the processes for assembling, preserving, and providing public access to these records, along with specific protocols for their review, disclosure, and secure handling. NARA subsequently provided guidance to federal agencies to identify, organize, and disclose UAP records for the new collection.

Sections 1687 and 7343 disallow use of funds or independent research and development (IRAD) indirect expenses for UFOs or UAP unless such material and information is made available the appropriate congressional committees and congressional leadership.

Language on the topic of UFO/UAP was also included in the previous 2023 NDAA, the 2022 NDAA, the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, as well as an accompanying Senate Select Committee on Intelligence report for the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021.

Foreign Extortion Prevention Act ðŸ”—

The Foreign Extortion Prevention Act (FEPA) enables US authorities to prosecute foreign officials who demand or accept bribes from a US citizen, US company, or within a US jurisdiction. FEPA addresses a longstanding gap in US anti-bribery legislation by tackling the “demand” side of bribery. At the same time, the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) focuses on the “supply” side of bribery.

Counter-extremist working group defunded ðŸ”—

Republicans opposed the anti-extremism working group created by Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin. That working group had been created by Austin after it became apparent that some service members and veterans had participated in the attack on the US Capitol January 6, 2021. That working group released recommendations at the end of 2021. Implementation, however, appeared to stall as Republicans increasingly opposed diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts in the military, which Republicans derided as “wokeness”.

Meanwhile, a recent inspector general report found dozens of troops, who appeared to be advocating violent overthrow of the US government.

The seriousness of this issue seems apparent from the fact that military and veterans have participated in other violent extremist events. For example, the Oklahoma City bomber, Timothy McVeigh, had served with distinction in Operation Desert Storm but had earned a reputation as a sergeant for assigning undesirable work to black servicemen and using derogatory language.

NATO withdrawal ðŸ”—

Section 1250A prevents the President from withdrawing the United States from NATO without the approval of a two-thirds Senate supermajority or an act of Congress.

Original proposals ðŸ”—

The original House bill contained provisions to:

  • Space Force Personnel Management Act: Disestablish the regular Space Force in order to integrate both active duty and reserve personnel into one Space Force entity. This is to allow for better flexibility for the Space Force by replacing “active duty” with “sustained duty” or “full-time” status, and replacing “reserve” with “part-time” status. This change would only pertain to the Space Force and not to the other armed services.
  • Elevate the position of vice chief of the National Guard Bureau to hold a statutory rank of general.
  • Permanently establish the titles of commissioned officer ranks of the Space Force to be the same as the Army, Marine Corps, and Air Force.
  • Authorize a $886 billion spending budget for national defense programs including:
    • A 5.2% pay increase for service members of the armed forces.
    • Procurement of up to 13 Virginia-class submarines.
  • Authorize the sale and transfer of defense articles and services relating to the implementation of the AUKUS partnership, including:
    • Up to three Virginia-class submarines, one year after this act is passed, however the Navy doesn’t intend implement this until 2032.

The Senate amendment contained:

  • UAP Disclosure Act: The Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena Disclosure Act of 2023 would direct the National Archives and Records Administration to collect and disclose records on unidentified flying objects (UFOs) or unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) no later than 25 years after enactment with a presumption of immediate disclosure. The U.S. president can certify that continued postponement can be made necessary by an identifiable harm to military defense, intelligence operations, law enforcement or conduct of foreign relations. The federal government would have eminent domain over recovered technologies of unknown origin (TUO) and biological evidence of non-human intelligence (NHI) that may be controlled by private persons or entities, such as aerospace companies. Legislation was necessary in part because UAP records had not been subject to mandatory declassification review due to exemptions under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 as well as an over-broad interpretation of “transclassified foreign nuclear information”.
  • The Intelligence Authorization Act (IAA) requires people currently or formerly under contract with the federal government to make all UFO/UAP material and information and a comprehensive list of all extraterrestrial or exotic UAP material available to the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office (AARO).
  • A provision that prevents the President of the United States from withdrawing the U.S. from NATO without approval of a two-thirds Senate supermajority or an act of Congress.

item.title: Ufology
item.description:
Ufology ðŸ”—

Ufology is the investigation of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) by individuals who believe they may have extraordinary origins, often extraterrestrial. While governments, private groups, and fringe science may investigate UFOs, ufology is generally considered pseudoscience by skeptics and science educators.

Etymology ðŸ”—

The term “ufology” is a neologism derived from “UFO” and the suffix “-logy.” Edward J. Ruppelt is credited with coining the term UFO. Early uses of “ufology” appeared in a 1957 Fantastic Universe article and a 1958 presentation for The Planetary Center.

Historical background ðŸ”—

Ufology’s roots can be traced to several historical phenomena: the “mystery airships” of the late 1890s, “foo fighters” reported during World War II, “ghost fliers” in the 1930s, “ghost rockets” in Scandinavia in 1946, and the Kenneth Arnold “flying saucer” sighting in 1947. The Arnold sighting significantly popularized the concept of flying saucers.

Increased UFO publicity after World War II coincided with the Cold War and concerns about Soviet aircraft. Official government activities related to ufology in the United States ended in the late 1960s after the Condon Committee report and the termination of Project Blue Book. Similar government-sponsored activities in other countries, such as the United Kingdom, Canada, Denmark, Italy, and Sweden, also ended. France is an exception, maintaining the GEIPAN program.

In September 2023, NASA appointed Mark McInerney as the Director of U.A.P. to study these occurrences scientifically and transparently.

As a field ðŸ”—

Ufology is not recognized as a scientific field of study by academia and is generally considered a pseudoscience.

Status as a pseudoscience ðŸ”—

Ufology is often listed as a pseudoscience because it lacks adherence to the scientific method, supporting evidence, plausibility, and falsifiability. Social factors contribute to this status, with some studies suggesting that mistrust between ufology, the sciences, and government bodies contributes to the perception of ufology as a pseudoscience. Poor science communication regarding the extraterrestrial intelligence (ETI) hypothesis also hinders public understanding and academic inquiry.

Current interest ðŸ”—

In 2021, Avi Loeb launched The Galileo Project to collect scientific evidence of extraterrestrials or their technology near Earth.

The University of WÃ¼rzburg in Germany is developing sensors to detect and analyze aerial objects for UAP applications.

A 2021 Gallup poll indicated an increase in the belief among Americans that some UFOs are extraterrestrial spacecraft.

In 2022, NASA announced a study to establish a roadmap for investigating UAP.

In 2023, the RAND Corporation published a study reviewing UAP sightings in the United States from 1998 to 2022, finding correlations between sightings and proximity to military operations areas.

Methodological issues ðŸ”—

Scientific UFO research faces challenges due to the unpredictable nature of the phenomena, lack of reproducibility, and absence of tangible physicality. Most UFO sightings have mundane explanations, limiting the interpretive power of extraordinary events. Carl Sagan noted that reliable cases are uninteresting, and interesting cases are unreliable.

J. Allen Hynek and Jacques VallÃ©e developed descriptive systems for characterizing UFO sightings and organizing ufology investigations.

Phenomena linked to ufology ðŸ”—

Certain phenomena are of interest to some ufologists, including crop circles, cattle mutilations, anomalous materials, alien abductions, and implants.

Some ufologists promote UFO conspiracy theories, such as the Roswell Incident, Majestic 12 documents, and UFO disclosure advocates.

Robert Sheaffer has accused ufology of a “credulity explosion,” where increasingly outlandish stories gain traction. James E. McDonald identified “cultism” and “extreme subgroups” as negatively impacting ufology.

In Posadism ðŸ”—

During the Cold War, ufology was combined with the ideas of Posadism, a Trotskyist movement in South America. Juan Posadas, the main theorist, believed humanity should appeal to extraterrestrials to help establish a socialist system on Earth. This belief contributed to the decline of Posadism as a political force.

Governmental and private ufology studies ðŸ”—

Starting in the 1940s, governmental agencies and private groups sponsored investigations, studies, and conferences related to ufology. These include Project Sign, Project Magnet, Project Blue Book, the Robertson Panel, and the Condon Committee in the United States; the Flying Saucer Working Party and Project Condign in Britain; GEIPAN in France; and Project Hessdalen in Norway. Private studies include those by the RAND Corporation, Harvey Rutledge of the University of Missouri, and the National Press Club’s Disclosure Project. The United Nations sponsored meetings and hearings concerning UFO sightings from 1977 to 1979. In August 2020, the United States Department of Defense established the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force.

UFO organizations and events ðŸ”—

Numerous private organizations worldwide are dedicated to the study, discussion, and publicity of ufology. Skeptic organizations also exist, emphasizing the pseudoscientific nature of ufology.

During World UFO Day (July 2), ufologists raise public awareness of ufology, including group gatherings to search for and observe UFOs.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFOlogists

item.title: David Grusch UFO whistleblower claims
item.description:
David Grusch: Former U.S. Military Intelligence Officer’s Claims About “Non-Human” Spacecraft Recovery ðŸ”—

This article focuses on the claims made by David Grusch, a former U.S. Air Force officer and intelligence official, regarding the U.S. government’s alleged involvement in recovering and reverse-engineering “non-human” spacecraft. It also covers the responses to these claims from various experts and government entities.

Background ðŸ”—

David Charles Grusch is introduced as an Afghanistan combat veteran and former intelligence officer who worked at the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) and the National Reconnaissance Office (NRO). From 2019 to 2021, he served as the NRO representative to the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force. He assisted in drafting the National Defense Authorization Act of 2023, which included whistleblower protections for UFO reporting. The section notes that Congressional interest in UFOs increased prior to Grusch’s claims due to the downing of four objects by the Air Force in February 2023.

Grusch’s Claims ðŸ”—

This section details the specific claims made by David Grusch. He alleges that the U.S. federal government maintains a highly secretive UFO retrieval program, possessing multiple spacecraft of “non-human” origin and the deceased pilots. He also claims there is evidence of white-collar crime to conceal these programs and that officials have stated people were killed to maintain secrecy.

Grusch further elaborated on his claims in an interview with Le Parisien, suggesting UFOs could be from extra dimensions and that the U.S. government transferred crashed UFOs to a defense contractor.

During a Congressional hearing in July 2023, Grusch testified that he was informed of a multi-decade UAP crash retrieval and reverse-engineering program, but was denied access. He stated that the U.S. government possesses UAP based on interviews with 40 witnesses. He also claimed the U.S. has retrieved “non-human ‘biologics’” from the crafts. When asked about harm or injury related to cover-ups, Grusch said yes, but could only provide details in a SCIF.

Responses from Relevant Experts ðŸ”—

This section presents the perspectives of various experts on Grusch’s claims. It highlights that his assertions are primarily based on alleged documents and conversations, rather than testable evidence. The scientific community generally views claims of government concealment of extraterrestrial visitation as untrue due to a lack of supporting evidence.

Joshua Semeter of NASA’s UAP independent study team emphasizes the lack of data or material evidence. Adam Frank, an astrophysics professor, criticizes the claims as hearsay. Stuart Clark’s opinion piece in The Guardian includes questions from scientists like Avi Loeb, Michael Garrett, and Sara Russell, who point out the lack of observed extraterrestrial activity and the ease of identifying extraterrestrial materials.

Greg Eghigian, a history professor, notes the historical pattern of individuals making “bombshell allegations” about UFOs without corroboration. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute questions the lack of physical evidence and dismisses the claims as an “argument from authority.” Michael Shermer of Skeptic magazine notes the absence of physical evidence and scientific community involvement.

Physicist Sean M. Carroll calls the evidence “laughable” and describes Grusch as a “complete crackpot.” NASA’s JPL director Laurie Leshin denies seeing spacecraft from outside Earth. Michio Kaku suggests the burden of proof has shifted to the Pentagon, a statement Ross Pomeroy criticizes as unscientific.

Responses from the United States Government ðŸ”—

This section outlines the responses from various U.S. government entities to Grusch’s claims.

White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre referred questions to the Department of Defense (DoD). The Pentagon stated that AARO has not discovered any verifiable information to substantiate claims of programs regarding the possession or reverse-engineering of extraterrestrial materials.

General Mark Milley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, stated he had never encountered evidence to verify Grusch’s claims. NASA stated it has not found any credible evidence of extraterrestrial life and no evidence that UAPs are extraterrestrial.

Representative Mike Turner, chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, stated there is no evidence to support claims of the U.S. possessing UFOs from outer space. Senator Lindsey Graham found the claims unreasonable. Senator Josh Hawley expressed less surprise, while other senators, like Kirsten Gillibrand and Marco Rubio, expressed concern about potential unbriefed special access programs and firsthand knowledge from individuals.

Senators Chuck Schumer and Mike Rounds proposed the UAP Disclosure Act 2023, an amendment to the 2024 National Defence Authorization Act, to increase access to UAP records. The enrolled bill directs the National Archives to collect government documents about UAPs.

Members of the House Oversight Committee’s national security subcommittee received a classified briefing from the Intelligence Community Inspector General (IC IG) Thomas A. Monheim regarding UAP reporting transparency. Some members expressed frustration with the lack of new information.

2023 House Committee Oversight and Accountability Hearing ðŸ”—

Representatives Anna Paulina Luna and Tim Burchett organized a hearing on July 26, 2023, in response to Grusch’s claims. Grusch testified, repeating his earlier UFO claims. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez asked where to look for evidence, to which Grusch offered to provide specific information in a closed environment. Officials later informed lawmakers that Grusch lacked the security clearance to discuss the issues in a SCIF. A bipartisan group of U.S. representatives called for the formation of a select committee on UAPs with subpoena power.

AARO’s director Sean Kirkpatrick criticized Grusch for refusing to speak with AARO and described the hearing as “insulting” to DoD and Intelligence Community officers.

Sean Kirkpatrick ðŸ”—

After retiring from AARO, Kirkpatrick wrote an opinion piece for Scientific American stating that the US Government UFO coverup allegations “derive from inadvertent or unauthorized disclosures of legitimate U.S. programs or related R&D that have nothing to do with extraterrestrial issues or technology.” He described the allegations’ supporters as “a small group of interconnected believers and others with possibly less than honest intentions,” who promote a “whirlwind of tall tales, fabrication and secondhand or thirdhand retellings”.

In an interview with Peter Bergen, Kirkpatrick said that Grusch may have misinterpreted things or fallen under the influence of a core group of people. He characterized the situation as a conspiracy by UFO true believers to get the government involved in investigating aliens, a “self licking ice cream cone”.

Media Reporting on Grusch’s Claims ðŸ”—

This section examines how the media has covered Grusch’s claims.

Connections to Studies Funded by Robert Bigelow ðŸ”—

Keith Kloor writing for Scientific American draws a connection between Grusch’s claims and studies funded by Robert Bigelow, noting the specific reference to “a football fieldâ€“sized UFO” in both Grusch’s claims and past claims by Bigelow.

Reporting on Psychiatric Treatment Received by Grusch ðŸ”—

Ken Klippenstein reported in The Intercept that Grusch was twice committed after incidents involving drunkenness and suicidal comments. Police records mentioned PTSD. Grusch was placed under an emergency custody order and transported to an emergency room, then transferred to an inpatient psychiatric program. The article noted that Grusch’s ability to keep his security clearance despite this history “appears to contrast with the government’s treatment of other employees”. Grusch later sued Loudoun County Sheriff for releasing the information.

News Stories and Commentary ðŸ”—

Nick Pope, who previously ran the British Ministry of Defense “UFO Desk,” expressed hope for confirmation but notes the difficulty given Grusch’s lost security clearance and lack of a “smoking gun.”

Marina Koren wrote in The Atlantic that the case fits a pattern of unprovable claims. Matt Laslo, writing for Wired, described the sympathetic hearing of Grusch’s claims by some members of Congress as an indication that once-fringe notions have built-in fan bases. Tucker Carlson publicized the claims in a video posted to Twitter and in an interview with Grusch. Tom Rogan, writing in the Washington Examiner, was skeptical but opined that the claims should be investigated.

Andrew Prokop, writing for Vox, noted that skeptics question whether Grusch is repeating tall tales and that mainstream media sources have remained wary. Sean Thomas expressed confusion that others have tried to convince officials and the public that UFOs are worthy of serious consideration. The New York Times columnist Ross Douthat noted that one interpretation is that parts of the U.S. government see benefit in promoting belief in UFOs. Matt Stieb, writing for New York, described Grusch’s claims as “crazy.”

Ezra Klein, a columnist with The New York Times, interviewed Leslie Kean, noting the polarized reactions to the story. Steven Greenstreet, a documentary filmmaker, criticized Grusch for associating with ufologists Jeremy Corbell and George Knapp.

The story received attention from multiple foreign mainstream news outlets.

Disinformation Campaign Allegations ðŸ”—

Grusch claimed that intentional disinformation was being promoted by the US government to cast doubt on the veracity of “non-human” UFO claims. Adam Gabbatt of The Guardian described Grusch’s position as “a common conspiracy trope in the UFO community”. item.title: 2022 United States Congress hearings on UFOs
item.description:
2022 United States Congressional Hearings on Unexplained Aerial Phenomena ðŸ”—

This article details the United States congressional hearings held on May 17, 2022, by the House Intelligence Subcommittee on Counterterrorism, Counterintelligence, and Counterproliferation to discuss military reports of Unexplained Aerial Phenomena (UAPs). It was the first public congressional hearing on UFO sightings in the US in over 50 years.

Background ðŸ”—

This section provides the historical context leading up to the 2022 hearings. It mentions the last public congressional hearing on UAPs in 1969, initiated by then-congressman Gerald Ford in 1966. Project Blue Book, a U.S. Air Force program investigating UFOs, was disbanded in 1969. The section also notes the 2017 reports of Pentagon investigations into UAPs and the 2020 COVID-19 relief bill that mandated a report on UAPs from US intelligence agencies. The unclassified report released in June 2021 is highlighted, noting its conclusion that 144 incidents defied explanation and called for further investigation. Finally, the establishment of the Airborne Object Identification and Management Synchronization Group (AOIMSG) in November 2021 and the provisions in the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022 and the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2022, for a permanent agency to investigate UAPs are mentioned.

Hearings ðŸ”—

This section details the events of the May 17, 2022, congressional hearings. Rep. AndrÃ© Carson, chairman of the subcommittee, opened the hearing, expressing concerns about national security threats posed by UAPs and criticizing the Pentagon’s lack of updates and leadership for the AOIMSG. Testimony was given by Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence and Security Ronald S. Moultrie and Deputy Director of Naval Intelligence Scott Bray. Bray stated that reported sightings had grown to about 400 since the previous year’s report and dismissed extraterrestrial origins. He also noted no collisions had been reported. The section mentions that other countries have similar reports and communicate with U.S. intelligence agencies. Moultrie emphasized the need for cooperation with the Federal Aviation Administration and other government agencies. Declassified images and footage of UFOs were shown, including a video of a “spherical object” and triangular objects seen through night-vision goggles. Concerns about potential Russian or Chinese hypersonic weapons programs were raised by lawmakers like Rick Crawford. The standardization of civilian reporting was discussed. The public portion of the hearing was followed by a private classified session.

Reactions ðŸ”—

This section describes the reactions to the congressional hearings. Rep. Tim Burchett criticized the Pentagon’s transparency and dismissiveness of extraterrestrial explanations. UFO skeptic Robert Sheaffer derided the footage shown at the hearing.

This section lists the sources cited in the article.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external resources related to the hearings, including the event page on Congress.gov, the hearing on C-SPAN, and a YouTube video of the hearing.
